fact: The iconic 'bullet time' effect was created using a rig of 120 individual cameras to freeze and rotate around the action.
James Cameron drew all of Jack’s sketches in the film himself — including the famous drawing of Rose.
Heath Ledger directed the Joker’s homemade hostage videos himself with minimal direction from Christopher Nolan.
The briefcase contents are never revealed, sparking decades of fan theories.
The rotating hallway fight scene was filmed using a giant spinning hallway set — no CGI.
Tom Hanks didn’t take a salary for the film — he instead took a percentage of profits, earning over $60 million.
Physicist Kip Thorne helped design the black hole so accurately that it led to scientific publications.
The wildebeest stampede took animators over 2 years to animate.
The cat Marlon Brando holds in the opening scene was a stray found on set.
The T-Rex roar is a mix of dog, penguin, tiger, alligator, and baby elephant sounds.
Oliver Reed died during filming, and some scenes were completed using CGI and body doubles.
The maggot fed to the crow was approved by the American Humane Association only after confirming it was dead.
There’s a Starbucks cup hidden in nearly every scene of the film.
Daniel Radcliffe went through 160 pairs of glasses during the filming of all 8 movies.

movie: Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back
fact: The 'I am your father' twist was kept so secret that even most of the cast didn’t know until the premiere.
‘Let It Go’ was written in one day and completely changed the story’s direction afterward.
Leonardo DiCaprio really ate raw bison liver for authenticity — despite being a vegetarian.
The time machine was originally a refrigerator, but was changed to a DeLorean to avoid kids locking themselves inside fridges.
The baby delivery scene was shot using a real engineering college's equipment and was supervised by actual medical experts.
Amjad Khan almost lost the role of Gabbar Singh because his voice was initially thought to be too soft.
The film has been running in Mumbai’s Maratha Mandir cinema for over 25 years — a world record for any film in a single theatre.
Lagaan was shot in Bhuj, Gujarat, in peak summer with temperatures going above 45°C. Most actors wore traditional attire without footwear.
The waterfall in the movie is CGI, and it took 1 year of VFX work to perfect the opening scene.
Aamir Khan wore clothes picked from real people on the streets to reflect his alien character’s randomness.
The village shown in the movie actually received electricity after the film crew left — inspired by the film.
Aamir Khan gained and lost over 25 kg during the movie to portray both older and younger versions of Mahavir Phogat.
Real MiG aircraft and air force cadets were used in the flying scenes for authenticity.
Ranveer Singh wrote and performed his own raps in the movie, inspired by real Mumbai street rappers Divine and Naezy.
Armie Hammer played both Winklevoss twins, with body doubles and face replacement used for many scenes.
Anthony Hopkins only appears on screen for 16 minutes but still won an Oscar for Best Actor.
The child actors were from real Mumbai slums and were later given trust funds and housing by the filmmakers.
Ranbir Kapoor prepared for the role by studying Charlie Chaplin’s body language to perfect the silent expressions.
The movie was a flop during its initial release but gained cult status through TV reruns and word of mouth.
Ajay Devgn's character uses classic techniques from real police procedurals to cover up the crime — all rooted in actual criminal cases.
The real Chris Gardner makes a cameo at the end of the movie walking past Will Smith and his son.
After the movie's release, psychologists coined the term 'The Truman Show Delusion' for people believing their lives were being filmed.
Wakanda's spoken language is based on real South African Xhosa, which John Kani (T'Chaka) taught the cast.
